newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Amnesty, U.N. condemn Cambodia grenade attack.
newsitem.headline: Amnesty, U.N. condemn Cambodia grenade attack.

text.p: A United Nations human rights official on Tuesday denounced a deadly weekend grenade attack in Phnom Penh as an attempt to wipe out the leadership of the main opposition party.

"This was a clear attempt to assassinate the leadership of an opposition political party who was conducting a legal and peaceful political demonstration," said Thomas Hammerberg, special U.N. representative for Human Rights in Cambodia.

Hammarberg, who said Khmer Nation Party (KNP) leader Sam Rainsy was the target of Sunday's attack outside parliament, added in a statement that he had "serious concerns about the possibility of a serious, professional investigation in this matter".
The U.N. official said he feared the killings and other violence had created an environment that could make the holding of free and fair elections next year much more difficult.

Amnesty International, in a statement dated Monday, condemned the attack, saying: "The incident appears to be part of a pattern of increasing political tension and violence, and is an extremely worrying development."

The London-based human rights organisation said as many as 19 people had been killed and more than 100 injured by four grenade explosions. Other reports have put the number of dead at anything from 14 to 20, with Hammarberg citing a figure of at least 16.
Amnesty said it feared for the safety of the former finance minister Sam Rainsy, who narrowly escaped injury.
Meanwhile, shock turned to anger as Cambodians reflected on the tragedy. In markets and streets, people expressed outrage.
At Wat Langka in the city centre, Sam Rainsy opened a book of condolences on Tuesday morning and received distraught relatives of those killed in the attack.
The family members sat with the remains of six of the victims. Many wept as they stared at the portraits of the victims on display, which were mounted in the centre of flowered wreaths.
The six were Sam Rainsy's bodyguard, Han Mony, as well as a KNP member, three young women who were garment factory workers and a 13-year-old girl who had come to watch Sunday's rally.
Cremation services were to be held at Wat Langka on Wednesday.
